name: Elephant
title: Animal
details: Elephants are the largest existing land animals. Three living species are currently recognised: the African bush elephant, the African forest elephant, and the Asian elephant. They are the only surviving members of the family Elephantidae and the order Proboscidea. Mass: Asian elephant: 4,000 kg, African bush elephant: 6,000 kg, African forest elephant: 2,700 – 6,000 kg Gestation period: Asian elephant: 18 – 22 months, African bush elephant: 22 months Lifespan: Asian elephant: 48 years, African bush elephant: 60 – 70 years, African forest elephant: 60 – 70 years Length: Asian elephant: 5.5 – 6.5 m Height: Asian elephant: 2.8 m, African bush elephant: 3.2 m Speed: African bush elephant: 40 km/h

name: Bears
title: Animal
details: Bears are carnivoran mammals of the family Ursidae. They are classified as caniforms, or doglike carnivorans. Although only eight species of bears are extant, they are widespread, appearing in a wide variety of habitats throughout the Northern Hemisphere and partially in the Southern Hemisphere. Scientific name: Ursidae Speed: Polar bear: 40 km/h, Brown bear: 56 km/h Lifespan: Giant panda: 20 years, Brown bear: 20 – 30 years Height: Polar bear: 1.8 – 2.4 m, Giant panda: 60 – 90 cm, Brown bear: 70 – 150 cm Higher classification: Caniformia Gestation period: Polar bear: 195 – 265 days,

name: Tiger
title: Animal
details: The tiger is the largest living cat species and a member of the genus Panthera. It is most recognisable for its dark vertical stripes on orange fur with a white underside. An apex predator, it primarily preys on ungulates, such as deer and wild boar.  Conservation status: Endangered (Population decreasing) Encyclopedia of Life Scientific name: Panthera tigris Length: 2.5 – 3.9 m (Male, Adult), 2 – 2.8 m (Female, Adult) Height: 80 – 110 cm (At Shoulder) Mass: 90 – 310 kg (Male, Adult), 65 – 170 kg (Female, Adult) Speed: 49 – 65 km/h (In Short Bursts) Size of territory: 60 – 100 km² (Male, Adult), 20 km² (Female, Adult)

name: Zebra
title: Animal
details: Zebras are African equines with distinctive black-and-white striped coats. There are three living species: the Grévy's zebra, plains zebra, and the mountain zebra. Zebras share the genus Equus with horses and asses, the three groups being the only living members of the family Equidae.

name: Crocodiles
title: Animal
details: Crocodiles or true crocodiles are large semiaquatic reptiles that live throughout the tropics in Africa, Asia, the Americas and Australia. Lifespan: Saltwater crocodile: 70 years, Nile crocodile: 50 – 60 years Speed: Saltwater crocodile: 24 – 29 km/h, American crocodile: 32 km/h, Nile crocodile: 30 – 35 km/h  Scientific name: Crocodylidae Clutch size: Saltwater crocodile: 40 – 60, American crocodile: 30 – 70, Nile crocodile: 25 – 80

name: Fox
title: Animal
details: Foxes are small to medium-sized, omnivorous mammals belonging to several genera of the family Canidae. They have a flattened skull, upright triangular ears, a pointed, slightly upturned snout, and a long bushy tail. Twelve species belong to the monophyletic  foxes group of genus Vulpes Speed: Red fox: 50 km/h, Gray fox: 68 km/hGestation period: Fennec fox: 50 – 52 days, Arctic fox: 52 days, MORE Encyclopedia of Life  Height: Fennec fox: 20 cm, Arctic fox: 25 – 30 cm, Red fox: 35 – 50 cm Daily sleep: Red fox: 9.8 hours Lifespan: Red fox: 3 – 4 years  Mass: Fennec fox: 0.68 – 1.6 kg, Arctic fox: 3.2 – 9.4 kg, MORE Encyclopedia of Life
